_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Humacao Filtration Plant is located at the State Road PR-198 kilometer 28.3 Barriada La Pra, Humacao, Puerto Rico, 00971. This filtration plant is owned by Puerto Rico Aqueduct and Sewer Authority (PRASA) which is a Government Agency.

PRASA has developed the RMP following the Program # 3 for the Management and Prevention of Risks associated with the storage and handling of the toxic substance used as for water disinfection: Chlorine. The RMP was prepared in compliance with EPA 40 CFR Part 68. The prevention program was prepared in accordance with OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) regulation as established in 29 CFR Part 1910.119.



Accidental Release:



It is PRASA policy to comply with EPA and OSHA Federal and Puerto Rican applicable requirements. Chlorine is a toxic substance regulated by EPA, for that reason Humacao Filtration Plant has undergone some engineering controls.  Changes have been put in place to improve sefety and as a part of the Prevention Plan implanted to protect the wellness of workers, employees, Contractors, visitors and immediately surrounding areas and inhabitants.



The Stationary Source and Regulated Substance handled:



Humacao Filtration Plant is located close to the area where the plant supplies the potable water. The Chlorine is used as a disinfectant to destroy the microorganism that could cause illness in humans.

The Chlorine is delivered from the PRASA Storage and Distributiong Center, Puerto Nuevo to the plant in 1 ton containers. The containers are connected to chlorinators from which the chlorine flows to the ejectors and the chlorine solution flow to two disinfection point. 



Worst Case Scenario:



The Worst Case Scenario was determined as indicated in the EPA Wastewater Treatment Plant, as per Appendix F, Supplemental Risk Management Program Guidance for Wastewater Treatment Plants. This guidance considers the release of the Chlorine Gas of the entire container (2000 lbs) during 10 minutes and other specifications re

lated to the weather conditions and a radio of 1.3 miles, for a Chlorine concentration equal or higher than 3 ppm, which is the American Industrial Hygiene Association exposure limit above which it is determined human health will be affected. 



Alternative Case Scenario:



The more realistic scenario was also simulated as per EPA Wastewater Treatment Plants parameters, as a release of the total content of a 2000 lbs container, but throughout a pipe leak. 



General Accident Release Prevention Program 



PRASA is actually close to implement a Prevention Plan to ensure the maintenance and mechanical integrity of the facilities which will improve significantly the safety scope of the current prevention plans. Different Standard Operational Procedures (SOP) are already in place to comply the OSHA and PROSHO requirements in order to keep all the involved parties aware of the hazardous and risk related to the Chlorine. List of all SOP are indicated in the PSM document and are located in the plant.



Emergency Response Program:



PRASA has various SOPs to manage emergency programs associated to a release of the Chemical and also related to the Emergency actions to be taken before and after hurricanes and other atmospherics events.                                                        

Five years Accident History:

No mayor release of chlorine in excess of 10 lbs has been reported during the last five years. 





Planned Changes to Improve Safety:



PRASA has already implemented in Humacao Filtration Plant, a vacuum operated system to improve the control of the process and the safety of the Chlorine handling and storage. 



Audits:



The last Audit was conducted on May 15, 2012. But during the past two years we have conducted internal metrics evaluation. With each metrics evaluation we request an action plan to correct the findings. PRASA has develop metrics evaluation to establish the level of compliance of our facilities with the RMP/PSM Program.
